name: Local Wild Life - Turtle Lake Refuge Recipes for Living Deep - Katrina Blair
description:
"Local Wild Life - Turtle Lake Refuge Recipes for Living Deep‚Äù by Katrina Blair is a 222 page recipe book on local wild, raw and living foods, published in 2009 in Durango, Colorado. 

If you'd like to order the book, scroll down to the bottom of the screen and click on 'add to cart'.

This compilation of wild, local, and living food (raw) recipes is more than a recipe book. It is a journey of eleven years of a community embracing the earth's bounty. It is a celebration of health from the individual to the planet. It is an inspirational path of action back to our roots where all beings are honored as kin.

Suggested Donation: $22

*******

TABLE OF CONTENTS

1) Introduction and Philosophies

- Intentions
- Our Beginnings
- Living the Juicy Life
- The Green Juice, the First and Most Important Recipe
- The Spices of Life
- Local Fruit is Heaven Here and Now
- Wild Weeds Are Our Greatest Resource
- Permaculture Plants
- An Introduction to Fresh Living Foods
- Equipment
- A Word about Salt and Seaweed
- Becoming a Sprouting Master
- Growing Microgreens

2) Core Turtle Creations

- Tasty Turtle Rosehip Granola Bars
- Chokecherry Macaroons
- Flaxseed Crackers
- Phat Nettle Oaties
- Silent Paradise Energy Balls
- Wild Mint Magic
- Raw Cacao Fudge
- Apricot Ginger Snaps
- Pumpkin Raisin Ginger Snaps
- Sprouted Rye Breadsticks
- Homemade Dried Granola
- Turtle Ice Dreams
- Kim Chee & Sauerkraut

3) A Wild Edible Feast

- Why Wild
- Benefits of Wild Foods
- Wild Water
- Wild Ingredients
- Local Wild Life Superfood
- A Note about Osha

4) Gourmet Local, Wild and Living Food Recipes

- Drinks
- Soups
- Salads
- Salad Dressings
- Sauces, Dips, James & Cheeses
- Sun Breads
- Main Dishes
- Desserts
- A Turtle Lake Refuge Recipe for Delicious Living
- A True Success Story

5) Full Menu Plans (January through December)

name: Raw Dried Edible Creations
description:
We dehydrate our products at 115 degrees Fahrenheit.

Flaxseed Crackers: flaxseed, carrots, coconut, ginger, Utah salt, amaranth seeds, curry powder, garlic, chili powder

Ginger Snaps: buckwheat groats, sunflower seeds, raisins, honey, ginger, apricots or peaches (depending on what's abundant), vanilla

Granola: honey, oats, sunflower seeds, raisins, buckwheat, almonds, tahini, flaxseeds, figs, oregon grapes, vanilla, cinnamon, apple sugar

Chokecherry Macaroons: apples, dates, coconut, chokecherries, filtered water

Nori Chips: sunflower seeds, mustard greens, sunflower greens, filtered water, tamari, pinon nuts or acorns (depending on abundance), ginger, nori sheets

10 oz. "Everything" Sample Pack: this includes samples of all 5 dried goodies. This comes in two small bags: one for "savory" and one for "sweet."

name: Local Wild Life Superfood Powder 4 oz.
description:
Local Wild Life Superfood consists of six local wild plants dried and ground into a fine powder. This can be used in smoothies, drinks and other recipes. The local wild greens may include Plantain, Dandelion, Lambsquarter, Amaranth, Mallow, Comfrey and Mint among others. The exact combination of herbs varies seasonally and according to what's locally abundant. These amazing plants are extremely rich in mineral content, enzymes, and chlorophyll.

Weight: 4 oz.

Suggested Donation: $9.50

NOTE: for international orders the superfood powder will be mailed in compostable plastic zipper bag as opposed to a jar to save on shipping costs unless you specifically want it in a glass jar and you're ok with higher shipping costs

name: Locally Made Apple Sugar (8 oz)
description:
Locally made Apple Sugar made here in Durango! It is made from the dried, blended pulp from juiced apples.

Ingredients: local apples (that's it!)

Suggested Donation: $5

name: Almond Granola - 1 lb.
description:
Ingredients: honey, oats, sunflower seeds, raisins, buckwheat, almonds, tahini, flaxseeds, figs, oregon grapes, vanilla, cinnamon, apple sugar

Dehydrated at 115 degrees Fahrenheit.
